title: Reviewing Season Pas debut on Apple TV ; Thiago Almada stunners : MLS Weekly
body_text:
Welcome to our new column collecting news, insights, and highlights from the world of Major League Soccer. This will be a team effort from all of our staff writers covering the league, but we‚Äôll start this first edition with one of our newest additions: Elias Burke, who will be reporting on American soccer from Los Angeles after covering West Brom and Derby County for our UK operation.
Advertisement
The opening weekend of the 2023 MLS season was‚Ä¶ interesting. From the comfort of my sofa, after having El Trafico postponed due to heavy rain, I ingested MLS on American soil for the first time as the league and Apple TV kicked off the season with an 11-game slate running from 1:30 to 9 p.m. Pacific. It was a long day.
The action on the field was largely solid. Thiago Almada stole the show with two stunning goals late to ensure Atlanta United fans left Mercedes-Benz Stadium delighted. Watching Wayne Rooney‚Äôs D.C. United turn over the fancied Toronto FC was pleasing also ‚Äî not so much because of any allegiance to the Black and Reds, but because Theodore Ku-DiPietro, the scorer of the winning goal in the 3-2 victory, has the coolest name in football.
While I sympathize with the effort of putting together 11 games in one day for the first time, the Apple TV experience was not without its hitches. But overall, it was an exciting insight into a league like no other. I can‚Äôt wait to do it again. ‚Äì Elias Burke
Season Pass is here
The good
‚Ä¢ If there was any room for immediate improvement under the new deal, it was on enhancing the quality of the match feed. With cameras and angles largely determined by each team‚Äôs local broadcast partner, jumping from one MLS match to another on ESPN could cause major whiplash with the broad array of picture qualities and sight lines.
Well, one thing is undeniable after Season Pass‚Äô debut: the picture quality is much, much better across the board. Last week, an article on the league website promised ‚Äúmore camera angles, 1080p video, Dolby 5.1 audio, and enhanced data and graphics in live match coverage.‚Äù The jump to 1080p was evident and a sight for sore eyes, making it easier to discern players from one another, to track the ball on the far end of the pitch and enhance the overall experience.
Advertisement
There were some issues, of course. At one point during Inter Miami‚Äôs opener against CF Montreal, there was a one-to-two-second delay between the match feed and the audio. Other matches experienced brief blips of darkness as a feed was momentarily cut, or strange errors with sound mixing or mismatched audio and video.
Still, the overall quality of the opening weekend‚Äôs feeds was far closer to that seen in Premier League broadcasts than MLS‚Äôs past baseline. That alone counts as a victory for Week 1. ‚Äì Jeff Rueter
‚Ä¢ Among MLS‚Äôs promises for Season Pass was that the broadcasts would do more to showcase things that make MLS special. To that end, I enjoyed a lot of little touches the broadcasts found time for throughout the weekend, especially when it came to fan entrances and pregame ceremonies, in particular Charlotte‚Äôs remembrance of club captain Anton Walkes, who died tragically this past offseason.
There‚Äôs certainly room to grow in this regard, but for a first effort prepared on a condensed timeline, it was nice to see. ‚Äì Alexander Abnos
Almost time! #MLS Season Pass won't be a flawless tonight ‚Äì there may be some hiccups* ‚Äì but it will 1080p steams with the best talent in the business.
Look for it to get better every week.
*None of you online are harsher critics than our internal expectations. pic.twitter.com/0oTDr0fWfo
‚Äî Mark McClure (@mrkmcclr) February 25, 2023
Major League Sales pitch
If there was one major complaint from the first weekend of MLS Season Pass, it‚Äôs that it felt at times a bit too much like an MLS infomercial. The opening game of the weekend, NYCFC‚Äôs visit to Nashville, was probably the best example in part because it was simulcast by Apple and on Fox as part of the latter‚Äôs English-language linear TV deal.
On Apple, the commentators pushed Nashville‚Äôs new Johnny Cash-themed jerseys constantly on the audience, even going so far as to say where they were for sale online. There was also discussion about the new MLS playoff format which included the assertion that it makes the regular season more important. That is undoubtedly up for debate, especially considering the fact that 63% of the league now makes the playoffs. While seeding matters in the playoff for home-field advantage, that was true under the last format, too.
It sounded like the goal was to get a national broadcast feel, but going to league talking points just makes this an MLS ‚Äúhomer‚Äù broadcast much in the same way local broadcasts felt for specific teams. It is understandable that MLS was celebrating the launch of this new broadcast ‚Äúnetwork,‚Äù but if the homer feel continues into the regular season it‚Äôs going to be tougher to stomach. ‚Äì Paul Tenorio
Advertisement
Wait til they hear about Hot G. Right
While it‚Äôs impossible to ensure a 100% level of accuracy with match subtitles, there were some glaring issues that will hopefully resolve as the season goes on. At one point during FC Dallas‚Äô match against Minnesota United, commentators were allegedly discussing United States international striker J. Zeus For Era. Apple users can attest to autocorrect‚Äôs ability to quickly learn a phone handler‚Äôs specific lingo; hopefully, something similar will happen here. ‚Äì Jeff Rueter
Fox‚Äôs barebones operation
‚Ä¢ The league should be furious at Fox‚Äôs lack of investment in its English linear deal. The network isn‚Äôt sending talent to games, instead flying them to broadcast out of the Vista facilities in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. The halftime DoorDash-sponsored ‚Äúset‚Äù behind Stu Holden and John Strong was evidence of the level of resources dedicated to this deal.
Not the most luxurious studio for Fox's MLS coverage. pic.twitter.com/jUhefIHoVN
‚Äî Nathan Tucker (@SportWatcherPRO) February 25, 2023
This isn‚Äôt anything new from Fox. They‚Äôve done multiple MLS games remotely in the past few years. A Washington Post report last year indicated Fox was prepared to ‚Äúuse mostly remote production and send a minimal contingent of staffers‚Äù to the 2022 World Cup before Qatar Airways sponsored the broadcast.
Still, considering that MLS decided to seek a linear partner for this season, it has to be disappointed with such a low level of investment. For a large portion of fans, the games on the Fox networks, especially those on over-the-air Fox like Saturday‚Äôs opener, will be their only exposure to MLS. A minor-league-looking set doesn‚Äôt communicate what the league and Apple are trying to project. ‚Äì Paul Tenorio
‚Ä¢ Say what you want about Fox‚Äôs janky halftime set, at least they weren‚Äôt trying to sell me a jersey every five minutes and reminding me how awesome and cool and revolutionary MLS is every 10 minutes. Strong and Holden‚Äôs commentary probably wasn‚Äôt as good as it would have been if they were there in-person, but it certainly wasn‚Äôt bad, and I appreciated being able to watch a game without quite so much forced salesmanship. If Fox can figure out a way to make its on-camera setup even slightly less embarrassing, then I don‚Äôt think the linear deal is all that bad. But there has to be a happy medium somewhere between their abdication and MLS‚Äôs indoctrination. I wonder who will find it first. ‚Äì Alexander Abnos
A weird whiparound
There is real potential for the whiparound show, MLS 360, but some kinks clearly need to be worked out. Early in the day, studio shots had the four co-hosts standing with their back to the camera, looking up at a giant screen. It was awkward and uncomfortable for the viewers ‚Äî and probably for the talent, too. They finally introduced chairs to the set and that made things much better.
AppleTV‚Äôs redzone-like MLS 360 show is going full Mystery Science Theater 3000. pic.twitter.com/526A0kMPg6
‚Äî Cork Gaines, Ph.D. (@CorkGaines) February 26, 2023
It‚Äôs also hard to fathom the sheer amount of commercials that appeared on the whiparound show. One thing that stands out about the format‚Äôs gold standard ‚Äì NFL RedZone ‚Äì is the lack of commercials, especially considering ad breaks make up a huge part of the normal football-on-TV experience. Here, MLS is asking you to turn off a sport that is commercial-free in order to watch a show that is filled with commercial breaks. And late in the night as there were fewer games being played, the commercial breaks ended up coinciding with goals several times. Not ideal.
One other weak point that will improve with repetition: learning when to lay out and just let the game and the broadcast tell the story. Thiago Almada‚Äôs dramatic game-winning stoppage-time free kick goal for Atlanta United is a great example. The crew started speaking immediately as the goal was scored, robbing the MLS 360 audience of the reaction from a crowd of 67,538 at Mercedes-Benz Stadium. One of the selling points of this league is the atmosphere in the stadium. Atlanta is one of the absolute shining examples for this league of the growth and popularity in local markets. Save the analysis for the replays. Let the environment tell the story that MLS needs to sell. ‚Äì Paul Tenorio
Advertisement
A jarring transition
No doubt, MLS and Apple are trying to create a distinct look for these broadcasts. However, the pivot from live action to a replay was jarring after just ten or fifteen minutes. The screen went all-black save for an MLS logo in the middle ‚Äî nothing too bizarre for an American sports broadcast. But the accompanying sound is an off-putting tone akin to pushing the wrong key on an old PC. If that continues to be the signifier for an instant replay, this viewer might prefer to save the highlights for after the final whistle. ‚Äì Jeff Rueter
En Espa√±ol
On the Spanish-language side, in-game analysis throughout the night was informed and astute. In Nashville-NYCFC Jorge Perez Navarro‚Äôs boisterous play-by-play contrasted nicely with Marcelo Balboa‚Äôs measured analytical tone and occasional bits of Spanglish.
The in-studio product later on Saturday night featured a mix of experienced voices and up-and-coming talent. Veteran host Tony Cherchi was paired with analysts Melissa Ortiz and former Portland Timbers superstar Diego Valeri. The nerves were evident at times, but Cherchi did well to keep the conversations flowing.
Valeri, who retired last summer while playing with his boyhood Club Lan√∫s, was especially impressive. He was composed and personable on camera and he displayed a deep knowledge of MLS teams and current players. Ortiz, who also does English-language sideline reporting for U.S. men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs national team games on HBO Max, did well in her second language. That‚Äôs not an easy task.
However, there was a notable lack of Latinos on the English-language side of the broadcasts. That‚Äôs a surprise considering the sport that‚Äôs being showcased and the coveted young bicultural Latino demographic that MLS wants to appeal to. There‚Äôs plenty of bilingual talent on staff so it could be simply a matter of mixing some of the studio pairings in the future.
The visual presentation and storytelling of the Spanish telecast mirrored the English feed. The look and feel, as well as the big picture storylines, were virtually identical. That was expected, but to start on Saturday, during the 4:30 pm ET slot, the studio and in-game graphics were in English on the Spanish feed. That later changed for the primetime matches.
Videos, like an excerpt of Don Garber‚Äôs interview with Maurice Edu, were presented without subtitles. That could be an intentional strategy to appeal to bicultural English-dominant Latinos or a sign that Apple and MLS don‚Äôt have the resources to provide that level of transcreation. ‚Äì Felipe Cardenas
On the field
Spirit of the Rams
As currently constructed, D.C. United bears some resemblance to manager Wayne Rooney‚Äôs Derby County side of 2021-22. That was one of the most remarkable teams in the English Championship that season, despite suffering relegation.
Advertisement
After being handed a 21-point deduction by the English Football League for entering administration and breaching the league‚Äôs profitability and sustainability rules ‚Äì akin to UEFA‚Äôs Financial Fair Play rules ‚Äì Rooney‚Äôs Derby side of academy graduates and free agents collected a series of upsets that drew plaudits across the country. These underdog wins earned him a reputation as a coach who can motivate young and inexperienced teams to beat highly-fancied opposition.
D.C. United showed the spirit of that Derby team against a Federico Bernardeschi-led Toronto side, after Italy international Lorenzo Insigne departed in the 31st minute with an apparent leg injury. Outside of a clumsy challenge to gift Toronto a penalty, 16-year-old Matai Akinmboni repaid Rooney‚Äôs faith by delivering a performance that belied his years in central defense, and 21-year-old Theodore Ku-DiPietro came off the bench to score the winner in the eighth minute of injury time to round off a spectacular comeback.
While Saturday‚Äôs win was a positive start to the season, D.C.‚Äôs pass map from the game‚Äôs first 68 minutes highlights the work still to be done to make D.C. a coherent outfit from back to front.
Of their 14 league wins that season, a significant portion came by way of late winners at home, where the defiant Pride Park support willed their team to victory. If D.C. United is going to improve significantly from last season, they must take the fighting attitude they displayed against Toronto, stabilize the defense and find ways to progress the ball more consistently. ‚Äì Elias Burke
Jim Curtin reads The Athletic
Or, at the very least, he saw the money quote from our annual MLS executives survey, in which one executive said that Curtin‚Äôs Philadelphia Union team, who are widely predicted to do very well this season and have been among the league‚Äôs best in recent years, are ‚Äúnot even that f‚Äîing good.‚Äù
The Union played like they had a point to prove to whoever said that (and perhaps some other people) in a dominant 4-1 win over the Columbus Crew. And then, this:
‚ÄúFirst of all, anonymous quotes are for cowards‚Äù ‚Äì Jim Curtin responds to the below comment, adding he did use it in yesterday‚Äôs film session with the team #DOOP https://t.co/QntF2TSkm1
‚Äî Meg Swanick (@Meg_Swanick) February 26, 2023
Almada show
Thiago Almada can really strike a ball. The 21-year-old from the Fuerte Apache neighborhood of Buenos Aires saved Atlanta United in week one with two highlight-reel goals from outside the penalty area. Both strikes came in stoppage time, erasing San Jose‚Äôs one-goal lead that had held firm for over 80 minutes.
Advertisement
A disciplined San Jose side had done well to frustrate Atlanta United‚Äôs attacking intent for the majority of the match. But big-money players are supposed to be big-time difference makers, and Atlanta United has a special player in Almada, whom the club paid a reported $16 million to acquire one year and one World Cup win ago.
Thiago Almada is HIM! üëÄ
The 21-year-old scored a 93rd-minute banger and a 99th-minute free kick to will @ATLUTD to victory. pic.twitter.com/2I3B2mzeu7
‚Äî Major League Soccer (@MLS) February 26, 2023
‚ÄúThiago with the first goal from outside the box, and then that amazing golazo to win the game‚Ä¶ It was special for us and I hope the fans are happy with it,‚Äù said Atlanta United manager Gonzalo Pineda after the match.
Almada‚Äôs talent has never been in question. He adapted to MLS right away in 2022 through consistent performances and game-changing goals. His late inclusion to Argentina‚Äôs World Cup roster, and the subsequent 30 days he spent training with the world champion Albiceleste in Qatar, has given him more confidence and sharpened his game before the 2023 MLS season.
Atlanta United always needs a showman. The soft-spoken Almada promises to entertain for as long as he‚Äôs in black and red. ‚Äì Felipe Cardenas
Driussi‚Äôs jaw-dropper
Austin FC will want to forget Saturday night‚Äôs humbling home loss to newcomers St. Louis City‚Ä¶with the exception of Sebastian Driussi‚Äôs ridiculous lob over St. Louis goalkeeper Roman B√ºrki. The goal tied the game in first-half stoppage time and reminded audiences around the world of how good a player Driussi truly is.
World class from El CRACK! üí• pic.twitter.com/BhbQ8DvEzd
‚Äî Austin FC (@AustinFC) February 26, 2023
It all happened pretty fast, but there‚Äôs a lot of planning that occurs inside a player‚Äôs head before he tries to chip a goalkeeper. Driussi either noticed B√ºrki was off his line as he made his deep-lying run or he caught a glimpse of the ‚Äòkeeper‚Äôs bright yellow kit before he deftly controlled Leo V√§is√§nen‚Äôs long ball. The end result was a masterclass in composure and opportunism from Driussi, with his weak foot. ‚Äì Felipe Cardenas
How does this happen?
Austin FC defender Kipp Keller‚Äôs giveaway to St. Louis‚Äô Jared Stroud seemed inexplicable at the time. Subsequent video review has revealed one possible explanation: That Stroud, who was Keller‚Äôs teammate in Austin last year, called for the ball as if he was still wearing green and black.
Advertisement
That would help explain Keller‚Äôs brain fart. But is that what happened? We might never know for certain, in part because this is the only video we have of the incident that‚Äôs legally shareable outside the Apple ecosystem:
Stroud back in Austin üòè pic.twitter.com/uRlAQNE7ch
‚Äî St Louis CITY SC (@stlCITYsc) February 26, 2023
For his part, Stroud told the St. Louis Post-Dispatch ‚Äúmaybe he recognized me,‚Äù in reference to Keller, who he called a ‚Äúgood friend of mine.‚Äù
Personally, I find it hard to believe anyone would be quite so devious to someone they call a friend. ‚Äì Alexander Abnos
Other notes
‚Ä¢ A genuine congratulations and ‚Äúnice job‚Äù to Minnesota United for getting an away win without talismanic playmaker Emanuel Reynoso to open the season. That‚Äôs an objectively great result. Still, feels like Game 1 of 34 might be slightly early for a ‚Äútough day for the experts‚Äù tweet. I‚Äôm sure the experts would all be totally ok with having their tough day at a later date, when the season is a bit more complete. ‚Äì Alexander Abnos
‚Ä¢ Serhiy Kryvtsov played 12 years for Shakhtar Donetsk in his native Ukraine before moving to Inter Miami this past offseason. Due to the ongoing conflict in the region, the defender hasn‚Äôt played in front of a packed, lively crowd in a while. His goal wasn‚Äôt exactly attractive, but it clearly meant a lot, both for him and an Inter Miami team that went on to win 2-0 at home over Montreal.
Kryvtsov on MLS: "It was beautiful, I forgot how it's like to play with fans (due to the situation in Ukraine.")
Says he thankful to the fans.
Mentions in Europe it's more technical, MLS there's more running and physical:
"It's just attack attack." #InterMiamiCF
‚Äî Alex Windley (@aaw_1998) February 26, 2023
What we‚Äôre hearing
Chicago Fire sign U-22 striker
(This item also appears in David Ornstein‚Äôs weekly column)
The Chicago Fire have finalized a transfer for PAOK forward Georgios Koutsias, a source with knowledge of the deal confirmed to The Athletic.
Advertisement
Koutsias, 19, is currently on loan to Volos NPS. The Fire will pay a transfer fee of $2.5 million for the young striker, who has two goals and one assist this season. Koutsias is seen as a replacement for Jhon Dur√°n, who was sold to Aston Villa for $18 million in the January window. Like Dur√°n, Koutsias will take up an Under-22 Initiative slot for the Fire. The Under-22 Initiative incentivizes MLS teams to buy players under the age of 22 to develop with an eye toward selling them.
The deal is expected to be announced in the coming days.
The Fire are also continuing to pursue a designated player at the No. 9 position. An earlier chase for Nottingham‚Äôs South Korean forward Hwang Ui-jo fizzled out, but the Fire remain in the market for a top-level forward.
Chicago also recently traded for former Sierra Leone and Middlesbrough striker Kei Kamara. The Fire will be the 10th MLS team for Kamara, 38, who has scored 139 goals in 16 seasons in the league. Polish striker Kacper Przyby≈Çko is also on the roster, but failed to impress last season with just five goals after moving from Philadelphia. ‚Äì Paul Tenorio
Preseason St. Louis concerns from a pair of MLS insiders
St. Louis City looked streetwise and opportunistic in its surprise win against Austin, making the Texans pay for shambolic defending. Before the season, though, multiple coaches and sporting executives expressed concern about the club‚Äôs roster, a decent chunk of which is made up by former MLS Next Pro players.
‚ÄúI think they‚Äôre underestimating the league a little bit,‚Äù said one source, a sporting executive at an MLS club. ‚ÄúI know Transfermarkt isn‚Äôt everything, but if you go through the values of the players on the team, Atlanta is at the top of the heap with ($56 million) and St Louis spends a third of that. A lot of those guys are MLS2 guys from last year ‚Äî they had success there, but sometimes that‚Äôs a curse. I know they want to be loyal to those guys, they took them to a championship. They have some decent role players but they took almost 10 guys and brought them to the first team. It‚Äôs going to be a long year.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt will be a miracle if they finish anywhere other than last place,‚Äù added another source. ‚ÄúThe league has grown a ton in recent years and you‚Äôd think they‚Äôd have learned from clubs like Cincinnati. You can‚Äôt roll out a USL lineup and succeed in this league, even if you play physical, direct football.‚Äù
Advertisement
For what it‚Äôs worth, St. Louis‚Äô best player on Saturday might have played in MLS Next Pro, but he‚Äôs also 26 years old with a few seasons in the German Bundesliga on his r√©sum√©.
Eduard L√∂wen ran the show for STL, assisting on Tim Parker‚Äôs opener and setting the table for Nico Gioacchini, who fed Klauss for the winner.
.@stlCITYsc GAME WINNER! üî•
Jo√£o Klauss with a beautiful turn and finish in the 86th minute to make history for #AllForCITY pic.twitter.com/15QqFqtzAg
‚Äî Major League Soccer (@MLS) February 26, 2023
Head coach Bradley Carnell has to be happy with that. ‚Äì Pablo Maurer
Hudson was set to join Houston
Current U.S. men‚Äôs national team interim coach Anthony Hudson was very close to joining Ben Olsen‚Äôs staff at the Houston Dynamo, multiple sources told The Athletic over the past few weeks. Hudson interviewed for a place on Olsen‚Äôs staff and seemed set to join the club before he realized he‚Äôd be needed to shepherd the USMNT in Gregg Berhalter‚Äôs absence. As of now, Olsen is complemented by ex-MLS player Aur√©lien Collin, former Crew and Dynamo assistant Tim Hanley and former Dynamo U-17 head coach Adin Osmanbasic. ‚Äì Pablo Maurer
A coach at Coachella
In October, Chris Wilder‚Äôs stint as manager of Middlesbrough came to an abrupt end. Despite the club‚Äôs aspirations to push for automatic promotion, the manager was sacked after 11 games with the club having won just two of those. Since then, the man who led Sheffield United to the brink of Europa League in 2019-2020 has been out of a job. Perhaps his next role will take him far from a Premier League push altogether.
In February, Wilder spent weeks around the Coachella Valley Invitational, per sources speaking anonymously to The Athletic to avoid linking him to any single club. Wilder, who has friends on participating teams‚Äô coaching staffs, was enjoying the matches and sunny weather in a break from the English winter. The sources did not link him to having tangible interest in an MLS role in the short-term, but did relay that he enjoyed the league‚Äôs level of play even in tune-up scrimmages.
One can‚Äôt rule out that seeds have been sewn, however. In December 2019, I was at the USL Summer Meetings and noticed that Anthony Hudson was catching up with folks in the lobby between sessions. The following month, he was announced as head coach of the United States U-20 program ‚Äî and, three years later, is the senior team‚Äôs interim boss. In short, this game has a funny way about it at times. ‚Äì Jeff Rueter
A word with Federico Bernardeschi
In mid-February, The Athletic caught up with Toronto FC‚Äôs Federico Bernardeschi during Toronto FC‚Äôs preseason preparations in California. There‚Äôs more to come this week from him, Lorenzo Insigne, Bob Bradley and new goalkeeper Sean Johnson on Toronto FC‚Äôs aims to swiftly return to the East‚Äôs elite.
For now, here are the Euro champion‚Äôs thoughts on what‚Äôs been a tumultuous series of events for ex-team Juventus and Serie A as a whole. ‚Äì Jeff Rueter
Advertisement
Are you surprised by what has come out regarding Juventus, with the points deduction and (Chairman) Andrea Agnelli and the board resigning?
No surprise, no. I (feel bad for) my ex-teammates, because for me, this situation is bad for them, and for the fans. But I think that Juventus is a big, big team in Italy, in Europe. Juventus has a great, great history behind it. For me, the next two, three years, (they) will go on to win. They‚Äôre gonna win. They‚Äôre gonna win.
In his press conference, Agnelli said that England is overtaking the sport and that Italy isn‚Äôt able to compete. Did you feel that Serie A was not as competitive as it was by the time you left?
No, it‚Äôs just people talking. Serie A is a great, great league. Inside the league of Serie A, there are many, many champions and great teams with great history. Now, for sure, the Premier League is the (best) league in the world. For sure. In the years of the 80‚Äôs, 90‚Äôs, 2000s‚Äô, it was Serie A (at the top). For me now, it‚Äôs a little process of change for the league of Serie A, but I think it‚Äôs great.
Beyond the field
FC Dallas fan Erik Tillisch was in the stands when his team advanced on penalty kicks against Minnesota United in the 2022 MLS Cup playoffs. He made sure of it, moving his first chemotherapy appointment to treat recently-discovered breast cancer to ensure he was at the soldout Toyota Stadium in Frisco.
During the match, Tillisch ‚Äì an FC Dallas season ticket holder since 2008 with his wife, Leslie ‚Äì held a white sign that said, ‚ÄúHi Paul, I start chemo Wednesday. Can I have your cancer shirt?‚Äù
It was a reference to the ‚ÄúF**K Cancer‚Äù undershirt Dallas midfielder Paul Arriola wore last season to honor his mother-in-law who continues to undergo treatment for stage 4 lung cancer.
Arriola saw the sign, and enthusiastically obliged.
Tillisch brought Arriola‚Äôs shirt with him to chemotherapy. He had it with him when he rang the bell, signaling his final day of treatment in December. And, officially in remission, Tillisch returned the shirt to Arriola Tuesday before the start of the MLS Season.
In October, STM @etillisch68 was set to begin chemotherapy for stage-2 breast cancer. To show his support, @PaulArriola gave him his "F Cancer" shirt. Arriola had been wearing the shirt all season.
Four months later, Erik returned the shirt, cancer free. pic.twitter.com/AVny2LIYAm
‚Äî FC Dallas (@FCDallas) February 22, 2023
‚ÄúI hope that, by giving the shirt back, the next person who receives it will find the same inspiration to fight that I did,‚Äù Tillisch told The Athletic. ‚ÄúIt got me through the lowest times of my treatment. It reminded me that there were others out there who were here to support me during that fight.‚Äù
Advertisement
Tillisch added his own message to the back of the shirt before returning it, ‚ÄúBe sad for a moment, be inspired, and fight for a lifetime.‚Äù
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt ever expect anything like this to come from me wearing the shirt,‚Äù Arriola told The Athletic. ‚ÄúWhat was the most special to me is just the inspiration that he has and the motivation that he has to also inspire others.‚Äù
Arriola, who got married in the offseason and watched his mother-in-law walk his wife, Akela, down the aisle, doesn‚Äôt have a specific plan for the shirt now, but he‚Äôs staying active in cancer organizations this season, specifically, Family Reach and Stand Up To Cancer.
‚ÄúLast year really opened our eyes,‚Äù Arriola said. ‚ÄúWe were able to see firsthand the impact that we can make on other people‚Äôs lives.‚Äù ‚Äì Emily Olsen
